text:
Your mouth will start to water 40 min. into the baking time as the aroma invades your home!!!  Since this makes 3 loaves, it is a great gift to bring over to neighbors and relatives, also great to freeze and  have on hand.
I will definetly use only half of the oil, and substitute the rest for unsweetened applesauce since it is 10g fat per slice.  It stays fresh in the fridge for a little over a week.  I had to cook mine for 70-75 min. but that is probably due to my oven.********So I tried this recipe again and put only applesauce and no oil.  The result?  Better!  It is so moist and delicious and healthier!  I have made it this way 10 plus times now and I will never go back to putting oil in it!  
********This lightened version is: 168 calories, 1 g fat per serving (36 servings).

text:
This is really great.  The only thing I did differently was I didn't measure out 3 cups of pumpkin.  I just used a 28 oz can.  You get about a half cup more pumpkin than called for, but it sure doesn't hurt it any, and I have no recipe that only calls for a half cup pumpkin.

Otherwise...GREAT!

text:
This was awesome!  The bread rose well and had a delightful texture and taste.  The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is becauset the original recipe would have been WAY too sweet with 4 cups of sugar that were called for.  I made it using 1 1/2 cups white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar as some other reviewers had suggested. And I think next time I may cut back by 1/2 cup.  I used applesauce in place of 1/2 the oil and thought that worked really nicely. I also recommend upping the spices to at least 2 or 2 1/2 tsp.  Especially the nutmeg!  Overall, a very yummy recipe--It made 2 loaves and 24 good sized muffins for me. (Muffins take about 22-24 min at same temperature).

text:
Yummy, yummy for my tummy!  Rarely do I follow a recipe to a T, so here are my additions: I added 2 tsp. of all the spices instead of the 1 1/2 tsp.  I also added 1 tsp. of allspice, 1 tsp. ginger, 1 tsp. pumpkin spice and my own secret ingredient, 1/2 tsp. dried Orange Peel.  One reviewer said they used Rum Soaked Raisins, but since we are not big raisin fans, I decided to add Brandy Soaked Dried Cranberries instead, which turned out great!  This recipe yielded 36 muffins.  Also, for those of you who are lost as to how long to bake the muffins, they bake for anywhere around 22-24 mins. depending on your oven.  P.S. I also just threw in a whole 29 ounce can of pumpkin puree.

text:
A good, dependable, classic pumpkin bread recipe that turns out just the way it's supposed to. Great as is, but would also be good with your favorite additions like raisins, nuts, or dried cranberries (which I had planned to add but couldn't find).  Prepared the recipe with no changes, only scaling this down to 24 servings for two loaves, using a 15-oz. can of pumpkin.  Baked perfectly at 1 hour.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!  Per others suggestions, I made a few changes: I used an entire 28 oz can of pumpkin, only 1/4 c. oil, and 1 1/4 c. applesauce.  This decreases the fat to 2 g per serving.  I also decreased the nutmeg to 1 tsp and decreased the sugar to 1 cup white sugar and 1 1/2 cups brown sugar.  It was delicious and still plenty sweet; it tasted like you could eat it for breakfast, not just dessert.  I also substituted all of the all-purpose flour with whole wheat pastry flour.  If you don't have whole wheat pastry flour, I'd substitute half of the all-purpose flour with regular whole wheat flour.  I also added 2 cups frozen cranberries.  Yummy!

text:
HANDS DOWN THE BEST EVER EVER EVER!!!!  Moist and simply fantastic!  Perfect for the holidays because it makes so much and it’s a real winner in the gift-giving department!  Here’s what I’ve done to it, but again as is, it’s just wonderful!  I use 2 cns. (15oz ea.) Pumpkin, 2 t. salt, 2 t. cinnamon, 2 t. nutmeg & 2 t. cloves.  Everything else stays the same.  To make it even more special, I make a topping for it that consisted of walnuts and sugar, and people often have told me that the topping is the best part too!  The topping may be good, but this fantastic bread deserves all the credit!!   Try it!! You won’t be sorry you did!!

text:
This one, by far, is the BEST!  I have tried three different recipes from this web site with 5 stars and this one is IT!  Why?  Because this bread doesn't have that dense, heavy home made texture.  This one is light, spongy, and moist.  I made 2 cupcacke trays and a loaf.  I put both cupcake trays in at the same time for 35 min.(then baked loaf seperately).   I made just  2 small changes:  I cut the oil  to 3/4 cup and added 3/4 cup of unsweetened applesauce.  I also put in 3 parts wht sugar and 1 part brown.  I sprinkled chopped pecans on the top and beautiful! Thanks Cheryl~ Love it!

text:
Very good!  In an effort to be a little more healthy, I made the following changes.  . .  Reduced sugar a little (used 1/2 brown & 1/2 white).  Used 1/2 canola oil & 1/2 applesauce.  Used 1/2 all purpose flour and 1/2 white whole wheat flour.  Doubled cinnamon and added a little vanilla.  I think it still could have used more cinnamon and other spices.  Sprinkled tops w/ turbinado sugar - Yum!  Baked mini-loaves for 30 min. & they were perfectly done.  Thanks for a nice pumpkin bread recipe!
UPDATE:  This time I made the full recipe.  Used whole 29oz can of pumpkin.  Used 
1 1/2c of white sugar and 1 1/2c of brown sugar. Added 2 T vanilla.  Used 2/14c all purpose flour and 2 1/2c of white whole wheat flour.  2 heaping T of cinnamon and about 2tsp or so each of cloves and nutmeg.  Definitely needs more spices than it has in original recipe.  Also still used 1/2 canola oil and 1/2 unsweetened applesauce.  The consistency and spice was perfect w/ the changes.  This is the best pumpkin bread recipe!

None
text:
This is a great recipe!! The other pumpkin breads I have tried from here weren't very good, so I was hestitate to try this. I sure am glad I did! I pretty much followed the recipe except I reduced the sugar by about a 1/2 cup (still was plenty sweet, believe me), used less oil (maybe 1/4 c less), used 2 cans of pumpkin 14.5 oz, added an extra tsp of each spice, added raisins, and nuts. My oldest daughter is allergic to nuts but the rest of us love them, so everything I make I fill one pan with batter, then add a cup of walnuts to the remaining batter so we can all enjoy what we like. Been working like a charm for 17 years. I would give this recipe more stars if I could. It is the exact texture I like my pumpkin bread, not dry, but perfectly moist. Even after 3 days it was better than when it was first baked. Keep it wrapped tightly in plastic so it won't dry out.

This was the second recipe I used for pumpkin bread this week.  The first was just so-so.  Thought my walnuts might have been rancid but decided to try another recipe (sans nuts).  This was fantastic.  It was so moist.  Very easy.  I increased the spices a bit as well since I like very flavorful things.  I'm a huge pumpkin bread fan and this is my new favorite recipe.  I didn't add nuts, chips, etc. and don't think it needs it.

text:
I made this recipe into muffins that my family could snack on during the day. Pumpkin is always great because it adds a lot of extra fiber, which sometimes is a much needed component of most diets. I cut this back to twelve servings. I didn't want to use a whole half cup of oil so I cut the amount by half and added an extra quarter cup of pumpkin puree. I also cut the sugar back to a scant three-quarters of a cup. The batter was a little dry (could have been because I messed with the serving amount) so I just added what was left in the pumpkin can (Trader Joe's 15 ounce can) and I threw in a teaspoon of vanilla extract. The muffins ended up getting a little overmixed which made them a little tough but they were very moist and had a nice flavor. 350* for about twenty minutes was just right--I got 12 biggish muffins out of a 12 serving adjusted recipe. Because I know what to add for next time to avoid that from happening, I'll write up my own custom version.

text:
Love this bread recipe but after reading many reviews decided to go for a healthier version. I used 4 cups whole wheat flour & 3/4 cup wheat germ in place of the flour;4 1/2 tsp. of pumpkin pie spice in place of all the spices; 1 1/2 cup applesauce in exchange for all of the oil; 3 cups of Organic Sucanat (free-flowing organic brown sugar in place of the regular sugar;and a 29 ounce can of pumpkin. I made muffins without muffin cups sprayed the pan with canola oil and baked at 350 for 20 min. Turned out good I am bringing them to a potluck at my son's school! YUMMY!

The point is, I just don't think you can go wrong with this recipe, whether you use it as written or as a starting point for your creativity. LOVE IT.

text:
This recipe was unbelievable.  I used the suggestions of other reviewers, and reduced the oil to 1 c., plus 1/2 c. melted butter.  I did 4 c. sugar, but half white and half brown, and I changed the spices, too: 2 tsp baking powder 2 tsp cinnamon 1 tsp nutmeg 1 tsp cloves.  With those changes, the spice combination was PERFECT.  Tasted just like what I think pumpkin bread should taste like.  It cooked faster in my glass loaf pan, but both loaves were incredibly moist (I made two loaves plus about 30 minimuffins).  I can't wait to show them off on Thanksgiving, and this is definitely my future pumpkin bread recipe of choice.  I can't imagine anyone having something bad to say about this bread.

Display Name:
Baricat

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1049439.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
In a word, WOW! This always turns out wonderfully moist. I have made it with pureed sweet potato, as well, and there is very little, if any, difference in flavor or texture. I sub Splenda for half the sugar, and no one who has not been told is ever any the wiser. I increase the spices according to my family's tastes, with the exception of cloves, and add 1-1/2 tsp ginger plus a generous dash of cayenne pepper for a hint of warmth. That never fails to make the guys go wild for this! I also add 2 Tb dark rum, which you can't taste in the finished product, but which adds a great depth of flavor, underscoring the spices to perfection. One noteworthy item...If made in a 9"X13" loaf pan as indicated, the resulting loaves are a bit shallow. It makes a much more impressive presentation if you bake it in a loaf pan of 8"X4", adding about 10-15 minutes to the baking time. Test at 50 minutes, then add time accordingly as necessary. Freezes well. What a fabulous recipe this is!

Everyone in the family (and preschool class) loved this recipe. userID:
3279861
Display Name:
Darcie
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First of all, I am not reviewing my variation of this recipe that may or may not resemble the original, my reviews are always on the recipe as written. 

As written this is one of the best pumpkin breads I've had. It's sweet but not excessively so, very soft, and almost perfectly spiced. Made in loaf or muffin form it's yummy, especially the day after you make it. 

Having made this recipe several times the past couple of years, both the recipe as written, and with some tweaks there are some changes I make that result in a five star recipe. You will note that I rated the recipe as written four stars. 

The four cups of sugar is excessive. I've been reducing the sugar a little bit since the second time I made this. At three cups this is still very yummy, and I prefer the level of sweetness. While I always recommend making a recipe as written the first time, ESPECIALLY if you intend to review it, this is improved with less sugar. Additionally, I now make this with an extra half cup of pumpkin, not only is this more convenient, but the bread is denser and I find the flavor to be a bit better. I have tried this 1 cup of oil and 1/2 cup of applesauce. The taste of the bread was unchanged but I'm not a fan of the sticky moistness that resulted on the top of the bread. Also, I find that adding 1/4 - 1/2 tsp more cloves than called for really elevates the flavor of this bread.

text:
Very Good Recipe. I did alter this recipe just a little bit. Instead of 4c. white sugar,I used 2 cups of brown and 2 cups of white sugar. I doubled the cinnamon & nutmeg to 3 tsp. (left the cloves the same) Instead of 1 1/2 c. veg. oil, I used 1/2c. butter+1c veg.oil. I also added 2 Tbsp of vanilla exract. I made muffins(plain, with walnuts, and with choc. chips)and they were devoured by the entire family. This is a recipe easy enough for children to enjoy.

Being English, I've never made nor even tasted anything with pumpkin in before, but when my American fiance said his mom made the best pumpkin bread ever, I knew I had to rise to the challenge! This is a good easy recipe, and I was delighted with the results! I made one plain loaf, one with pecans and another with choc chips. My only complaint was that it was a little on the dry side - next time I will add a little more oil. Thanks for a great recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've tried other pumpkin bread recipes on allrecipes and this one is the best. Like other reviewers I use one large can, which adds a bit extra pumpkin, so I reduce the oil just a little, maybe 1/8 cup and I add an extra 1/2 tsp of cinnamon, just because I like it. You can definitely taste the clove flavor. I think it's nice, but if you don't care for cloves, you might want to reduce it. It makes excellent muffins also. What I offen do is make one loaf with mini chocolate chips (my fav), one loaf with chopped walnuts on top, and a dozen muffins, and I bake them all at once. Keep an eye on it. Mine sometimes gets done a little early and starts to get too brown on the edge so I reduce the heat part-way through to about 325. I took this to Thanksgiving this year and my husbands grandmother said it was the best bread she'd ever had.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe received rave reviews from all ages tonight!  I was in charge of non-pie desserts for Thanksgiving and with all my planned baking done, two hours left to spare, and two lonely pie pumpkins sitting on my counter, I decided to throw this together.  I made a few slight mods... 3 cups of fresh puree (so much better than canned - worth the small effort), replace half of the regular sugar with dark brown sugar, replace half the oil with apple sauce, and replace half the white flour with wheat flour.  I baked it in a bunt cake pan for 50 min.  There was so much extra batter that I also made 12 cupcakes and a 8" round flat pan (each of those baked for 25 min).  Finally, I drizzled it all with a simple icing. Wonderful!  I will certainly make it again.

text:
I have made this twice and my family LOVES it!  The first time I made as written and it was a five star bread.  The second time, I made it a bit healthier by following Sara Jane's recommendation of replacing the oil with applesauce, and I also cut the sugar to three cups (two white and one brown) because that was all I had in the house.  My family liked it even better that way!  We've eaten the full batch (yes, three loaves worth) in just a week!  My kids love it spread with peanut butter.  This makes great muffins, which cuts down the baking time and makes for a more portable snack.   This is the only recipe for pumpkin bread I will ever use.  Thanks Cheryl!

text:
This is exactly like the recipe my mom gave me, I was so upset because I couldn't find it.  I started making this with fresh pumpkin, then switched to the canned pumpkin puree, and now use the pumpkin pie mix which eliminates having to add the spices separate.  My own mom didn't even notice (she makes everything from fresh pumpkin) and it saves a few steps, always received many compliments.  I will try it with unsweetened applesauce instead of oil like I read in one of the reviews.  I have never had a dry loaf, after I take them out of the oven, let them cool for a few minutes then wrap them in plastic wrap while still warm and put em' in the fridge immediately, leave in overnight.  Even if the top is a little hard (had a crappy oven once; temp issues) it makes everything moist.

This has always been a family favorite, just as is and great to give as a gift.  Since I make it so often I have lightened up the recipe.  I use applesauce instead of oil, I use all egg whites, only 3 cups of sugar and I add 1 cup of flax seed meal.  That way I can still make some with the mini chocolate chips and enjoy it too!  Try roasting your own pie pumpkin and pureeing it yourself, so awesome!

text:
Great bread! 

I made 3 loaves like the recipe calls for-- using 2 whole cans of pumpkin. The glass dish seemed to bake best. I would reduce heat when using darker pans.

I substituted 1 C applesauce and 1/2 C Butter for the oil, and 1/2 tsp ginger for the clove. I also added 2 tsp's vanilla, for a smoother flavor.

A great holiday treat!

text:
I loved this recipe.  A wonderful fall-time nasty weather treat.  It made the house smell so good while it baked.  Smelled like holiday time!  I did make some modifications though, that some may want to consider:

*Only did 1/3 recipe to make a single loaf
*used whole wheat flour in place of 1/2 of the regular flour
*used applesauce for 1/2 of the oil
*used 1/3 cup brown sugar, the rest Splenda
*added 1/3 cup stewed raisins (raisins are so much better if you soak them for a bit in hot water before adding to a recipe!)
*added 1/2 cup chopped pecans
This recipe is sooo good.  Lots of raisins and nuts make it like a dessert, but without fat or much sugar and whole wheat flour, it is pretty darned healthy!

Wish I could give this more stars!  It is out of this world good!  I made it exactly as directed however I did add about a 1/2 cup of chopped pecans and  I cut the recipe into 1/3's and made one big loaf.  I used real butter and melted a couple tablespoons in the pan and used it to grease the pan well before putting in my batter.  Made for a buttery crust.  I had to cook for about 20 minutes longer than directed probably because of my cheap oven.  The bread came out moist and dense on the inside and nice and crunchy on the outside.   I will be making this over and over again!  Perfect recipe for fall!!!

text:
This is my new favorite pumpkin bread recipe!    I subbed 1/2 cup of the oil for applesauce and changed the spices around a bit to suite my tastes.  Very good, make sure you dont overbake - mine went from almost done to done very fast.    ETA:  I've made this twice now and have figured out I need to take the bread out when the toothpick has some "doughy" crumbs on it...when I let it cook till it comes out clean, its just a bit overcooked - still moist and good, but better when taken out just a little sooner than I think I should.  I also like to glaze my pumpkin bread - I use a box of powdered sugar and pour in milk, small amt at a time till I get a nice thick consistency.  Add a tsp or so of maple flavoring and drizzle over the top of the loaves while still warm.  I use the throw away pans and pull them out so the glaze runs down the sides of the bread.  I like to freeze the bread, it seems to be even moister after thawed out.

text:
So good! I used up the last of our homemade pumpkin puree (soooo easy to make...Cut the top off, cut pumpkin into wedges, clean out the "guts" and seeds....no need to be perfect...roast the wedges at 350 degrees for about 45 minutes. Then, use a serrated knife to peel away the skin. It will come off so easily. Mash the pumpkin, adding a little water at a time to get the right consistency, then use or freeze it in freezer bags....WHEW! That was a lot of typing!). Anyhoo, this was some delicious pumpkin bread...One of the best recipes I've ever used. I substituted about 1 1/2 tablespoons of pumpkin pie spice for the cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves. I also added about 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract, and it was so yummy! Thanks for an awesome recipe!

userID:

Display Name:
COOKIEGYRL

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This bread is excellent!  It is very moist and thick, but not too heavy.  It should be noted that I live in high altitude area before I give my tips...

First, I usually try the recipe as is before I change it.  But since I am not a fan of cloves, I added 1 tsp of pumpkin pie spice and a half teaspoon of ginger.  Also, for some reason, I felt the urge to add brown sugar, so I substituted 1 cup of white for 1 cup of brown.  
This is probably a no-brainer for an experienced baker, but for a novice like me, you want to make sure to rotate the loaves in the oven so each one is in the middle for the same amount of time.  I ended up leaving the loaf in the middle for too long before rotating, and that one had to bake ten minutes longer. Also, I thought the tops were getting a little hard towards the end (not burnt, just hard), so I added foil to the top of each one for the last 10-15 minutes of bake time.  Two loaves baked for about 50 minutes, and the other for an additional 10 minutes or so.  After they cooled in the loaf pan for 15 minutes or so, I quickly removed them and covered them in foil again.  This definitely kept the moisture in, and the top of the loaves were soft again!  
Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Yup, this is the one to die for.  I liked this recipe a lot because you can use the large can of pumpkin puree, unlike most pumpkin bread recipes.  The other plus is that this calls for half baking powder and half baking soda.  Don't fall for those recipes that call for all baking soda because you can really taste it in the bread.  The only change I made to this was to cut the oil down to one cup.  This recipe really is "the best".

text:
Love love this recipe!! I had previously tried the Maine Pumpkin Bread recipe (also on this site); but this beats it, hands down.  I did make some modifications per the recommendations of other users.  First, I replaced all the oil for applesauce (1:1 ratio).  Second, I only used 2/3 of the recommended sugar servings.  Third, I doubled the cinammon & nutmeg servings.  Fourth, I added ginger and pumpkin spice, as well as a dash of vanilla.  Lastly, I threw in some chocolate chips ( I would recommend mini-chocolate chips).  The result was pure deliciousness.  Here's another tip:  Heat the bread for a few seconds so that the choco chips melt into the bread.  
This is my go-to bread recipe.  Seriously delicious and easy to make.

I hate to be different, but I really thought this bread was ok, but not spectacular.  The amounts of eggs, oil, and sugar could really be cut back and the cooking time was off for me.  I think it's a great starting point for making your own recipe with derivations, but as it is, it could use some work.  There are a lot of pumpkin bread recipes out there that work better as they are written.

Warning--If you're not too fond of cloves, reduce the amount to less than 1 tsp.  I had already reduced cloves to 1 tsp. and increased the cinnamon to 2 tsp. and I felt the bread tasted way too much of cloves.  I would suggest 1/2 tsp of cloves.  The recipe is technically good, and i did replace half the oil with applesauce.  Very good other than the cloves!!  I will make this again with less cloves.  Good quantity for sharing.

text:
Great bread, but it didn't have enough of the spice flavor, and also I prefer larger/taller loaves. I used 4 1/2 cup sugar, between 4-5 tsp cinnamon (maybe more), an extra shake of nutmeg, and between 4-5 tsp cloves (maybe more). Also, instead of making 3 small loaves, I divided the batter between 2- 9x5 bread pans.  After these small changes, it went from 4 stars to AMAZING!!!!! :) Great recipe!!!

text:
I doubled the spices but omitted cloves, as I didn't have any. Baked about an hour in disposable 9.5x6 pans. This bread is excellent -- Very moist and dense, but not TOO dense, just fluffy enough. A nice mild pumpkiny flavor that's not too spicy or sweet. Next time I would probably add more spices and perhaps use ginger as well so there's a bit more bite. I imagine this will taste just delicious with a cup of coffee. I made a loaf with milk chocolate chips as well, which came out good, but the milk chocolate was a bit too sweet and overwhelms the pumpkin flavor -- I'll use less chips next time and maybe use semisweet or white chips instead. Overall a tasty bread and I'll make it again.

Display Name:
Andi Martin
isPro:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was a bit leary over the size of the recipie...but I had two 15oz cans of pumpkin to use, so I figured 'what the heck'.      I brought a piece to my boyfriend, who had just gotten out of the shower. As soon as he had the bite in his mouth, he dropped to his knees in front of me on the bathroom floor and said, "I want you to stay with me for the rest of my life." =) I'll be using the recipe again, for sure!    I think the original recipe calls for way too much sugar- I used 2 C lightly packed brown sugar, and 1 C Sugar in the Raw, substituted 1/2 C gingerbread yogurt and 1/2 C butter for the oil, and added 3T pumpkin pie spices, 1 T cinnamon, two pinches clove, and a pinch of nutmeg. The recipe baked quickly with 3 minutes to spare from the 1 hour mark. They were very dark brown on top, and at first I was afraid I had burnt them- but it's just a darker bread. The bread is *very* moist. I wouldn't use any more than 1 C of oil/butter substance if you use 30oz pumpkin puree.  I made it in one 9x5" pan and a larger 9x11" pan. I will be taking some to my families' Thanksgiving....if we don't eat it all first!

text:
This is the best Pumpkin Bread I have ever tried!!! It is so moist(even the next day)and flavor rich that there is no reason for butter or cream cheese and with me that is a must. But this bread is just too good to to mess with! I followed the recipe almost exactly only a few minor changes, like someone else I used the whole can (29oz) of pumpkin, I always add a little extra spice(just about doubled what was called for). I added a pinch of salt (be careful more than a pinch would ruin it fast!) and a bit of vanilla and of course walnuts. Oh yeah I replaced 1/2 cup of sugar with 1/2 cup of brown sugar. Also I baked it on 350 for 50 than turned the oven off and left it in there for about an hour because it was not fully cooked and i had to leave. What a wonderful thing to come home to! The whole family loved it and so did the neighbors who could smell it cooking at their house and had to try some.  I am going to try it in my pumpkin roll for the holidays. This recipe is a keeper!!! Happy Baking!

text:
Wow I was surprised at how moist and delicious this pumpkin bread is! I did make several substitutions for a healthier recipe. For the oil I used 1/2 cup applesauce, 1/2 cup banana yogurt, and 1/2 cup oil. I also used 1 cup of wheat flour in place of a cup of the white flour. I made three 8x4 loaves and they came out wonderful. One change I will make next time is to reduce the spices slightly (I enjoyed it as is but it's a little strong for my family). Thanks for the recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/62158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am sure this recipe is wonderful as is, but for anyone who wants to change it up to make it a bit more healthful, here is what I did.  And it was very tasty!!

For the oil, I used olive oil and substituted half of it with applesauce.  I used turbinado/raw sugar in place of the white sugar, and cut it back 3 cups and added 1/2 cup of molasses.  I used 4 cups whole wheat flour in place of all-purpose, and added 3/4 cup of wheat germ.  I left off the cloves because I didn't have them.  I also threw in about a cup of chopped walnut pieces, then sprinkled some of the chopped nuts over the top of each loaf before putting it in the oven.

I guess by the time I finished, it was like a whole new recipe, but it tasted really good and I was able to feel pretty good about eating it!

text:
This pumpkin bread is sooo good!!  Years ago I had a recipe for pumpkin muffins that was given to me in a home economics class I had to take in high school.  They were the best tasting pumpkin muffins I had ever had, but being young and careless I misplaced the recipe and never found one that came even close to having the same wonderfully moist and delicious flavor.  I've tried many different pumpkin muffin and bread recipes over the years and not one could compare...until now.  This pumpkin bread is the absolute closest I have come to finding a recipe that could replicate the great flavor of those pumpkin muffins from years ago.  I love it and this recipe is one that I plan to hang onto for years to come.  Thank you so much for sharing it!

text:
Love this recipe!  I've made it too many times to count and it always turns out perfectly.  Key is to make sure it's done after the 1 hour of baking.  Toothpick can't have a drop off wet dough on it or the  top of the loaf will not be done.  Be patient! :)  I love the large recipe as it uses up 1 large can of pumpkin exactly even though it's slightly too much pumpkin and it turns out great.  I freeze the extra loaves that don't get devoured in the first 2 days.  My kids and husband LOVE this recipe and it smells amazing while baking.  Perfect fall and winter recipe.

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pumpkin Awesomeness. I have been making the recipe for years. Its the first thing we do to celebrate the beginning of Fall.  I am always asked for the recipe. It is easy to make and very adaptable. It is perfect the way it is, however we change it up sometimes by adding nuts (pecans, walnuts, or even pumpkin seeds), or dried fruits (raisins, cranberries). Its sweet like a cake, you can reduce some of the sugar and it is still great. The recipe is huge, it makes 2 loaf pans (one for us, one we share with friends), but you can easily halve it. I can serve it to my dairy free friends, it makes great french toast, or a fall flavored bread pudding. The blend of spices is perfect. My husband was a former pumpkin hater, after eating this he was willing to eat pumpkin in other recipes as well.  Would not be fall without it!

text:
Made this for the first time a few weeks ago and made a loaf, then made some batter into muffins to which I added chopped walnuts and garnished with a half walnut on top half way through baking.  This let the walnut toast just a little.  I packed them in a pretty box for another friend's birthday.  They were a HUGE hit! I made the rest into mini loaves.  NOTE: This recipe makes a TON of batter, I had to use the crock from my slow cooker to do the final mix as I had no bowl big enough!

text:
O.M.G. This was great! The only change I made was to use 1/2 tsp. less cloves and add 1/2 tsp. ground ginger in their place. Also, FYI, a 29-oz. can of pumpkin puree is just about 3 cups. That's what I used. People raved about this one. I think it would be great with walnuts too, and maybe dried cranberries! Oh, and DO make it at least a day before you plan to serve it. It's MUCH better ... more flavorful and moist ... the next day and beyond!

None
text:
This recipe is fantastic and easy! Thank you for posting it! I've made it three different times now; once as muffins and a large loaf, and twice as triple loaves. EVERYONE loves these! You know how some recipes have a different outcome each time you bake them? Not this one, its a no failure, same results, wonderful dense bread. You can eat plain, cold, warm, add stuff to it, or butter it. It tastes better the longer you leave it in the fridge(hopefully not too long its so good), and from what I hear-freezes well. The only thing I did differently was add the entire can of pumpkin, and it was actually pumpkin pie filling, not puree so there was tons of flavor. Also, I just substituted 4.5 teaspoons of pumpkin pie spice for the single spices, which is the exact equivalent of adding up the three individuals. Make this, you won't regret it!!

text:
I made one large loaf in a 9x5" glass Pyrex loaf pan and 17 large muffins.  The muffins were done in about 32 minutes, (I sprayed the muffin tins with Baker's Joy and they slid out perfectly when done) and I had to bake the loaf for an additional 20 minutes (checking every 10) because the middle was gooey.  Both the loaf and muffins were so delicious!  The spiciness is on the milder side so if you like your pumpkin bread spicier, definitely increase the spices. My 8-year-old and husband went wild over them.  They are even better the second day.  My family just finished everything up and are already asking when I am making more.  Next time I will increase the spices and try them with less oil to see how they taste, but honestly these are incredible as is!!!

text:
The flavor of this bread was delicious!  I followed the recipe exactly, and think everything was well balanced, except it is very oily.  In my opinion, 1 1/2 cups vegetable oil was a LOT of oil.  Next time I make this, I would substitute apple sauce (or even more pumpkin puree) for half of the oil.  Also, I was missing some kind of textural contrast... some kind of crunch or chewyness.  Next time, I will add walnuts, or raisins, or craisins, or a combo.  This is a solid, basic, and delicious recipe, but I look forward to making it again with these changes to better suit my tastes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a really quick & easy recipe. I made a few changes: I used 1/2 whole wheat flour and 1/2 white flour, 1/2 brown sugar and 1/2 white sugar, replaced the oil with unsweetened applesauce, and used pumpkin pie spice instead of the cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves. The result was a dense, delicious bread that was ready in 1 hour. My big complaint with this recipe is that there is just WAY too much sugar. When combining the sugars in the beginning I just kept thinking that it sure seemed like a lot, and I was definitely right - the crust on my loaves are sticky to the touch! Next time I am going to use half the sugars and I'm sure it will turn out just as good.

What a wonderful recipe! I just made a batch into 2 loaves and 15 muffins. Tastes delicious! I used two 15 oz. cans of pumkin because thats what I had in my pantry, I substituted unsweetened apple sauce for the oil, used 2 cups brown sugar and 2 of white suger, and 4 1/2 tsp apple pie spice rather than the separate spices (my apple pie spice has cloves, cinnamon, allspice, nutmeg). text:
This receipe was so easy and delcious! I made 1 9x5 loaf and one bundt pan of it. I baked the bundt for 45 minutes and it came out perfectly. The loaf I baked for 5-10 minutes more. I used all applesauce in place of oil, reduced the sugar to 3 cups instead of 4, and used 2 3/4 whole wheat flour and the rest of the 2 cups was all purpose and added a little more of each spice. I also made a cream cheese glaze to put on the bundt. YUM :)  Next time I will use all whole wheat. I made this for a crowd this time and was afraid that it was going to come out too dense if I used all whole wheat...but I believe I was wrong!  Great go to recipe.

I cut the the recipe by 1/3 (scaled it to 24 servings) and used 1/2 cup of oil (instead of 1 cup)and 3 cups of pumpkin instead of 2.  I baked it 55 minutes and it was perfectly baked.  I used a silicone loaf pan and it fell right out of the pan--no sticking--I use silicone bakeware exclusively by the way.
Anyway, the pumpkin bread was very good, we all loved it.  It wasn't as sweet as I thought it would be, but that's OK, it was still delicious and I will make this over and over again.  Next time I am going to add an extra teaspoon of Cinnamon and a tsp of ginger.  I'll let you know how it comes out!

text:
HEAVEN in a loaf pan!  This bread is absolutely, positively AMAZING!  I did sub 1/2 applesauce for the oil, added 1/2 tsp vanilla and based on personal preference for spices used: 2 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1 1/2 tsp nutmeg and 1/2 tsp cloves.  The result?  A perfectly moist, not overly sweet or spiced, OH SO YUMMY bread!  It baked up beautifully in just over an hour, and not only did we get delicious pumpkin bread after that hour, our house smelled beautifully!  I live in Australia where anything "pumpkin" (cakes, cookies, breads) is very rare and all of our friends who have tried this bread just LOVE it and ask for the recipe!  This is most definitely a keeper!

text:
I gave this 4 stars because I changed a few things. I doubled the spice as some reviewers suggested. I cut the sugar by 1/2 cup and it was perfect. If I used what the recipe called for it would have been way too sweet.

 I used one whole can of pumpkin  (28 oz) which was a little more than the recipe called for and it didn't one bit!  I also used 1 cup of butter and 1/2 cup of oil. I prefer the taste of butter. I sprinkled some brown sugar on top of the loaves before cooking.

Some great additions would be walnuts or raisins.

My hubby and son loved the bread. They ate all 3 loves in two days. It's even better the next day. The loves freeze well if you don't need all of them at once. I am making them this week for a bake sale.

text:
This recipe is so delicious!  A couple of changes I made was instead of oil I used a 6oz container of vanilla yogurt, and 3/4c of unsweetened applesauce.  I also just used a whole large can of pumpkin which was 30 oz I believe. 
Instead of 4c of sugar I used the equivalent of 1c in regular splenda (I think it was 24 packets, or you could use splenda granulated), as well as 1c of splenda brown sugar blend, and it was plenty sweet.  Instead of regular flour I used whole wheat flour.  It ended up cutting out so many calories, and I got excellent results!  This is a great recipe, so easy to make.        I think next time I will use half whole wheat half regular flour, as they did taste a tad "healthy", but still sooo good.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this 5 stars for the direction of the recipe because I hardly changed this and it was YUMMO! It's a perfect recipe for making gifts for neighbors and family. The batch really makes a lot.  I got two 8.5" x 5" loaf pans, and 10 very large muffins out of just one batch.  This is super-moist and easy, easy, easy.

Here is what I altered: 1)You can definitely reduce the sugar! I used 2 1/2 cups sugar and 1/2 cup packed brown sugar.  Then, I drizzled  1/8 honey into the wet mix. 2) I pureed my own pumpkin and did not use canned pumpkin. 3) I added 1 tsp each vanilla and butter flavoring. 3) I only had 3/4 cup veg. oil, so I used another 3/4 cup of applesauce.

Give this a try!

text:
I have made this twice and it is delicious...here are my substitutions.  I used 1 cup oil and 1/2 cup of applesauce, 3 cups white sugar and 1 cup golden brown sugar, I used pumpkin spice instead of cloves.  I made 1 loaf (45-60 min), 3 small loafs (40 min), and 12 muffins-filled high (20 min).  I freeze them and pull them out when I have guests.  They taste even better after they have been frozen.  Tip for moms...my two year old did all of the measuring and I did all of the stirring, it was a great memory.

text:
I found this recipe a year ago and have been making two loaves monthly since! My 2 year old loves it. I  use walnuts and sometimes flaxseeds for an extra nutritional kick. Also, I decrease the sugar and oil just a bit, and add more pumpkin to keep it moist. Nobody seems to mind! Also, I replace the flour with 1/2 c. whole wheat flour per loaf. Before we stopped using soy, I would replace 1/2 the oil with tofu. If it is blended well in a food processor, you truly cannot tell it is there. This recipe can become extremely  healthy with a little tweaking.

text:
This recipe is awesome - moist and just the right blend of flavors!  However, instead of 3 regular loaves, I make 5 mini loaves (and bake for 30-35 minutes).  For gift giving, I wrap each loaf in aluminum foil and put a bow on top.  I then place it in the middle of a doily covered decorative plate and add Christmas cookies all around it.  I then place it in the middle of a large sheet of colored cellophane, draw the cellophane around the plate and tie with fancy curled ribbon.  People look forward to my "Christmas Platter" every year!  These loaves freeze very well, so I make ahead and then thaw when ready to use as gifts!

text:
This bread was very tastey! I used 3 cups white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar. Also did not add cloves or nutmeg since we were all out and used 2 teaspoons of cinnamon.  I did add one bag of mini chocolate chips. I made two 9 by 5 loaves and one pan of mini breads (like a muffin pan but the shape of mini loaves).  I took some of the mini breads to the neighbors and the loved them and wanted the recipe. We called it Halloween bread since it had pumpkin and chocolate.  My husband did not like it because of the chocolate chips... Also we froze a loaf and this bread does not freeze well, it tastes best after sitting a day or two wrapped at room temperature, freezing seemed to dry it out a lot and I ended up throwing the defrosted loaf out.

text:
This was a good recipe.  I cut it down to enough for one loaf, but decided to make muffins in the end.  They turned out good, and were a hit with my family.  The only change I made, and the reason I only give it 4 stars, is that I ended up almost doubling the amount of spices that went in to get it to a flavor level that I like, based on the aroma coming from the batter.  My instincts turned out to be right, because I, and my family, thought the spice level I chose was just right.  But I would guess that if you don't like strong flavors, the amount called for in the original recipe is probably perfect.

Absolutely perfect!! Lightly crispy top with a wonderfully flavored soft inside :)

It's a week later, I've made this several times now each batch a little different from the last. 
1 - the first batch was exactly as the recipe recommends. Perfection!
2 - the second I made with sweetened applesauce instead of oil,  reduced the sugar, and used pumpkin pie spice instead on the other spices. tasted like a lovely harvest bread with the pumpkin and apple!
3 - this last batch I ran out of sugar so it was half white sugar half Splenda type sugar, again with pumpkin pie spice. Still so very good!

text:
Delicious!  I've been making this recipe for years now.  I use a Kitchen Aid mixer and put everything in the bowl at once and beat until smooth.  I also put raisins in and boil them about 5 minutes before putting them into the batter.  This way they do not go to the bottom of the pan. My family likes pecan nuts best of all, so that is what I use. I give at least 15-20 loafs out every year as Christmas gifts.  My family and friends look forward to getting one as they say it's the best pumpkin bread that they have ever had.  Also, it's a good gift for the mailman, paper man etc.

If I could give this recipe 10 stars, I would!  We added semi-sweet chocolate chips (YUM!!!!!). I only had one bread pan so I improvised: used the bread pan and spread the rest in a 9"x13" pan.  That baked quicker than the bread pan and I cut what was in the 9"x13" into 3 loaves once it cooled.  Kept one loaf out to eat and froze the rest.  I have been pulling one loaf out of the freezer daily since we can't get enough of it!  Defrosts easily and doesn't change the taste!

text:
Yum!! This is so good! I've never liked pumpkin before until this week-I've been obsessed. This bread has a very light and smooth texture. It's not dense or heavy tasting like most breads. I wire wisked all my dry ingredients together - I'm not sure if that had anything to do with it but I know when I sift my dry ingredients using a fine mesh strainer (when I bake cakes) it makes the texture light as air. This bread is very moist. The top center of mine was still a little raw when I took it out of the oven. I put it back in for 5 more min and it still wasn't completely cooked. I couldn't wait any longer so I just ate it like that. It tastes like soft pumpkin bread with pumpkin pie in the middle. Next time I make this I'll add pure vanilla xtract but it's perfect the way it is.

text:
I loved this bread although I did make some changes. I scaled it down to only 1 9x5 loaf and I used a stick of melted butter instead of oil. Used 1 1/4 cup of sugar and 3/4 tsp cinnamon 3/4 tsp nutmeg a scant 1/2 tsp cloves and a scant 1/4 tsp ginger. It's delicious. Next time a may use a mixture of brown and white sugars (the outside was a little crisp from the white sugar I think) and might substitute half the butter out for extra pumpkin (or yogurt). Very versatile recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just had to comment on this luscious recipe! It's quick to put together, and you are rewarded with "3" plum, delicious loaves! I made the recipe "as is", adding some chopped walnuts and raisins stirred into the batter at the end before filling the pans. My bake time was longer as well - 65-75 minutes, depending on the amount of batter in the pans.....the results, however, were superb! Just what I wanted....fragrant, not-too-sweet, wonderfully moist pumpkin bread!  I kept (1) loaf and gave two away as gifts.....the recipients were very happy!  I may try using one part white whole wheat flour in place of the AP white flour, and, as others have suggested, applesauce, to replace some or all of the oil. I hope it turns out as well with those changes. Overall, a WONDERFUL recipe!  PS...while it's baking, take a few minutes to wash the bowl, etc....when the bread is done, so are you! Just put on the coffee, cut a fat slice, and enjoy!

text:
This is a great recipe.  I made it as written.... delicious, but not very healthy. But no one knew that my new version was good for you.  The pumpkin and spices are what makes it so good (and the chocolate chips of course).
I substituted white, whole wheat flour for the all purpose flour.  You can always use a combination of the two to equal the 4 3/4 cups.  There is way too much sugar...it's not necessary. I used 1 1/3 cups each of white and dark brown sugar (I might try all brown sugar next time). I used 2 whole eggs and 7 egg whites (again, you can change the combination). I also substituted 1 1/4 cup of unsweetened applesauce plus 1/4 cup oil. And of course, I added a handful of mini chocolate chips.  Delicious!

Made this recipe but only used 1 cup oil & replaced remainder with 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce. Took recommendation from another baker that only used 1 1/2 cups white sugar & 1 1/2 cups brown sugar. Increased spices to 2 tsp for cinnamon, nutmeg & cloves....turned out delicious & much lighter than normal dense pumpkin bread. My girls loved it!!! The recipe made 8 mini loaves cooked for 30 minutes & 2 large loaves cooked for 55 minutes.

text:
This recipe is really...REALLY good! I used fresh puréed roasted pumpkin instead of canned (WAY better!), half white and half whole wheat flour. Also, I used only 1/2 cup oil and 1 cup unsweetened apple sauce. I thought that 4 cups was a lot, so I only used 2 cups white sugar, and 3/4 cup brown and it was perfectly sweet. I made one large loaf, two small loves with walnuts on top, and then mixed in dark chocolate chips and chopped walnuts and made blondies and everyone raved. This recipe is a keeper...with my modifications it was lower fat and calories (I am on weight watchers...with my subs it is 4 points per serving)

I've been making this recipe (with all organic ingredients) for years now with a few changes. I use one 15 ounce can of pumpkin (of course, fresh pumpkin is always best when available!) and then halve all of the other ingredients for two nice loaves. userID:
2181610
Display Name:
Kris Maas
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
58
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this and it is DELICIOUS!  I did make a few changes (I know, I know - everybody hates it when people do that, but I couldn't help it!)  First, I was running low on oil, and I had a 29 oz can of pumpkin, so I used the whole can (3.5 cups) plus 1/2 cup applesauce, and 1/2 cup oil.  I don't think this hurt the recipe one bit, as it's still moist and yummy.  I was also running low on sugar, so I used 2 cups white sugar and 1 cup brown sugar.  Finally, I did increase the amount of spices used, but that's personal preference.
This recipe makes a LOT of batter.  A LOT!  I made 12 muffins, a 9x5 loaf pan, and another smaller (8x4?) loaf pan.  For half the muffins and the smaller loaf pan, I added "Cheese Filling" from Pokey-Turtle.  Historically, I have issues with cakes and muffins never rising for me - they always turn out flat and ugly.  I don't know if I overmix or what.  But these turned out BEAUTIFUL!  The tops were nice and round.  I was so proud to pull them out of the oven!  I baked the muffins for 30 minutes and the two loaf pans for one hour.
I thought the cheese filling was the perfect touch - like a pumpkin roll without the hassle.  
I will definitely be making this bread again!

text:
5 stars!  I altered the recipe somewhat, and it came out great!  Used 28 oz can of pumpkin; reduced the oil to 1 cup; reduced the sugar to 3.5 cups (but added 1 cup of raisins plumped in warm cranberry juice at the end for sweetness); replaced 1 cup of the flour with whole wheat flour; and added 1 cup of toasted chopped walnuts at the end with the raisins.  Came out great!  A huge Thanksgiving hit!

This is a delicious and easy recipe. I broke it down to 24 servings (2 loaves) and substituted half of the oil with half applesauce and it was very moist. I think it actually enhanced the flavor. I also added 2/3 cup dried cranberries, which made it even better. I took it to my staff meeting, and everyone gobbled it up. The good thing about breaking it down to 2 loaves is that it is perfect for one small can of pumpkin without any waste. Great recipe, will definitely do again with the cranberries.

Display Name:
Yum
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took this recipe, substituted some ingredients to make it healthier and gluten-free and it turned out great!  My kids love it!

Instead of the oil, I use the same amount of apple sauce (I love "PC Just Apples").  Instead of sugar, I use 2 cups of Agave.  Instead of flour, I use the same amount of "Bob Mill's Gluten-free Flour".  Then you need to add about 2 tsp. of Guar Gum to bind the flour.

It turns out moist and yummy every time!  And there's little guilt in eating it!!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I've made this several times to rave reviews. I make these into mini muffins (12 doz) and freeze some of them for the kids to have as snacks in their lunches.  My changes: reduce sugar to 3 cups, Replace 1 c oil with 1 c unsweetened applesauce, Increase to 2t cinnamon, reduce to 1t nutmeg, add 1t pumpkin pie spice.  Sometimes I add pecans or mini chocolate chips too.

text:
My first try at pumpkin bread.  I substituted 1/2 cup butter for part of the oil and added 2 bananas. I only had one 15 ounce can of pumpkin but I had a 9 ounce jar of Pumpkin butter so I used that to bring it up to 3 cups.  Had to bake it a little longer and I might cut that back a tad to about 65 minutes.  It is very tasty. I think it would be good warm with vanilla ice cream or with a lemon curd sauce.  I will be baking this one again.

text:
I've made this several times.  Such an easy recipe to make!  I do use the foil pans for this recipe though.  They are smaller in size than regular loaf pans, therefore, this recipe will yield four pans of bread which means, depending on your oven, the bake time will be a little longer.  I also use applesauce instead of oil.  This makes the bread quite moist even after being in the fridge for a day or two.  Excellent recipe!

text:
I want to thank all of you who have taken this recipe and made it their own. I too make adjustments.  I continue to make all size breads and muffins as gifts wrapped and tied with fall ribbon, as well as for my boys who are now men and still cannot wait  for Oct. and Nov. when I make this bread for the fall. (sometimes Dec. I am a seasonal baker.)  What I do for gifts is to take my batter divide it,  put mini chips in one part,  hold my loaf pan kind of holding it on a tilt, put half choc.chip batter one one side and then fill the other side with plain batter smooth the two together and top with roughly chopped toasted walnuts.  This way I can give a choice when cut from both sides. I did post a photo finally.  Not a cut look though.  I will take another photo to show how that looks this week and post another photo. I just wanted to take the time and let  you all know that I appreciate your kind words. Thanks Cheryl

Sinfully amazing.  I make these into muffins and this recipe makes three dozen.  Just use the whole can of pumpkin as it's just over 3 cups.  I've been toying with ways to make it healthier, but after ruining the recipe once with too many substitutions, currently my only change is to use 1 cup applesauce and 1/2 cup oil instead of 1-1/2 cups oil and 1-3/4 cups whole wheat flour in place of the same amount white flour.  Honestly it is perfect with no changes, I am just doing what I can to make it slightly less sinful!

This is an awesome recipe.  I made some substitutions to cut back on the fat/calories.  Instead of the 1 1/2 cups of oil, I used 3/4 cup oil and 3/4 cup of regular applesauce.  Instead of the 4 cups of sugar, I used 3 c. sugar and 1/2 c. of sugar/splenda blend.   The bread was very moist, just the right level of sweetness and the flavor of the spices creates the perfect pumpkin bread.  I will be making this for years to come.  I also like the idea that it makes 3 loaves.  No one would ever know that I made the substitutions.

text:
The only reason I'm giving this 4 stars is because I modified it slightly. I used a full 29 oz. can of pumpkin so I didn't have to measure it. I replaced the oil with unsweetened applesauce (great idea!) I split the sugar half white and half light brown. Used 2 3/4 cups all-purpose flour and 2 cups whole wheat flour. (I have a 2 year old.) Omitted the spices and replaced with 5 teaspoons pumpkin pie spice and 1 teaspoon cinnamon. Also added 1 teaspoon vanilla. I made muffins and it yielded 48+ (I ran out of muffin cups after that so I had to toss the remaining batter.) Sprinkled the batter with decorator's sugar before baking to give it a sweet crunch. Bake for 15-20 minutes depending on your oven at 325. So delicious!!!

text:
This recipe made some very tasty pumpkin bread.  I only made two thirds of what the recipe called for and only made two loaves.  I made a couple of changes: (1) I wound up using more pumpkin than the recipe called for - this may have made the bread slightly more moist than I anticipated. As a result, my bread was not 100% cooked through after one hour.  It was close though.  (2) I added a teaspoon of pumpkin pie spice and slightly reduced the amount of cloves called for. (3) Instead of oil, I used half oil, half unsweetened applesauce.  This resulted in a delicious bread with a strong pumpkin flavor.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
We just moved to Nepal (4,000 ft above sea level) and I decided to use this as my first trial baking recipe. I was tempted to up the flour as most high altitude recipes suggest, but decided to just try the recipe as is. In short, it came out great! I was waiting for the bread to sink and turn into a hard lump of bread, but no such thing. It rose up (and stayed up) beautifully. It wasn't overly moist, I will definitely keep this in my collection. Thanks!

text:
I followed the instructions of another reviewer and did 1/2 the recipe and made 4 mini-loaves.  I tried one with rum-soaked raisins, one with walnuts, one with mini choco-chips, and the last one plain.  I did substitute half the oil with applesauce and hardly found a deficit in taste and texture.  The walnuts were definitely the most popular, and we all ended up slathering the breads with some cream cheese frosting I had leftover from another recipe.  That was definitely a tasty addition!  I only give 4 instead of 5 stars b/c I think the spice ratio needs to be tweaked - maybe more cinnamon and less nutmeg.  Great, nutritious bread - lovely with tea.

text:
This made 2 regular sized loaves, 1 medium loaf & 3 mini loaves.  The texture is good.  I did use 1/2 cup apple sauce in place of 1/2 cup of oil and 2 cups white sugar + 2 cups Splenda, to cut down on some of the calories & fat.  I did not have the cloves, so I used the 1 1/2 tsp of each spice and then added 1 1/2 tsp of pumpkin spice.  I sprayed the pans with non-stick cooking spray and then dusted them with cinnamon/sugar mixture.  I used one of the mini loaves to sample.  Nicely flavored sweet bread.  I can't wait to give these as gifts!

I am crazy over anything pumpkin flavored- This bread is AMAZING!!  I use canola oil but cut it back by about 1/2 cup and use an entire can of pumpkin since I love that extra flavor.  I make sure and add all of my basic pumpkin pie spices and I could just eat this bread all day long!  THE BEST EVER!

*Tip* To get a soft, moist crust just cover the loaf in plastic wrap or place it in a covered cake dish/tupperware for a couple hours when it it still slightly warm! YUM!

Everyone said = Really Delicious. this recipe calls for a vast amount of ingredients, so I cut back white sugar to 2 cups and used 1/2 cup packed brown sugar, 1/2 cup applesauce in place of 1/2 cup of oil and had to use a little pumplin pie mix, which has a bit of sugar already in it. It made 32 muffins and I filled the empty muffin cups with 1/4 of water to even out the baking process. 30 minutes in 350 convection oven. MMMMMMmmmmmmmmmm

text:
This stuff is delicious! I brought 2 loaves to a party (where they were promptly devoured), and we kept the 3rd for ourselves. This stuff gets better every day! I did make a few minor changes. I added roughly an extra cup of pumpkin. Instead of 1 1/2 tsp of each spice called for, I added 2 generous tsp. I also threw in 2 generous tsp of pumpkin pie spice, and a handful of mini chocolate chips. With those little changes, this was THE perfect pumpkin bread. Super-soft, cake-like texture.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/586101.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My whole family loved this pumpkin loaf!  Although, I took a few suggestions from others here and altered a few ingredients. I added 2 cups of brown sugar in lieu of just using white.  I also replaced 1/2 cup of unsweetened applesauce and only used 1 cup of oil instead of the 1 1/2 cups. Lastly, I added 2 tsp of vanilla and only 1 tsp of the ground cloves.  The loaves turned out great!  Oh... I did have to alter my baking time also. It ended up taking an hour and 15 minutes for the loaves to bake fully.  I am not sure if that was due to me changing the amount of oil and adding the applesauce or if it was because I used shiny metal pans instead of the dark non stick kind. But whatever the case, the loaves turned out moist and so flavourful!  This recipe is definitely a keeper! Thanks! :)

Really great recipe!  I also cut the oil in half and used applesauce which worked out fine.  I used 2 fresh sugar pumpkins which gave me about 4-1/2 cups of pumpkin puree so I just used it all! I was looking for a good pumpkin bread recipe and I think I've found it. I made this recipe yesterday and it went over well with my husband and son. I did substitute 1 cup of sugar for 1/2 cup of brown sugar and I used 1/2 cup vegetable oil and 1/2 cup applesauce.  So moist and delicious!

text:
This is a great recipe.  I changed it a bit to add a slightly different flavour.  I use a scale for metric and converted the recipe to metric. I used 131 grams of whole wheat flour, 131 grams of oatmeal, and 131 grams of white flour. Bascially that means I substituted white flour, whole wheat flour and oatmeal in equal parts to replace the all-purpose flour.   I also doubled the cinnamon, because I love cinnamon.  I will certainly make this recipe again.

text:
This was a wonderful recipe! I scaled down the recipe to 24 servings and ended up making 1 9 x 5 loaf and 8 muffins. I ran out of white sugar, so I ended up using 1/2c white sugar, 1/2c splenda, and 1 1/2c brown sugar. Also used 1c all-purpose flour and 1c and 2T of wheat flour. The result was absolutely divine. Be sure not to overbake it! I think it's best when the middle is very moist and even slightly undercooked.

text:
I tried this recipe tonight for the first time. After reading several changes other people had made, I did the same thing. I replaced the oil with unsweetend applesauce in place of the oil. I also reduced the sugar to 1 cup white sugar and 1 1/2 cups of light brown sugar. For the flour, I used self rising flour so no need for the baking powder, soda. or salt. The spices I increased to 2 tsps each. I used one 29 oz can of pumpkin. At the end I added a cap of pure vanilla. This made 4 loaves. One I made plain, one with raisins, and 2 with raisins and chopped walnuts. This is a dense bread but delicious! I couldn't wait for it to cool. I cut 2 small slices and put butter on top because the loaf was still warm. Delicious! My little dog thought so too! I will be making this again! Great idea for Christmas gifts!

text:
This bread was excellent. I made it for dessert at a friends house  and  everybody raved. I did make a couple of changes because I don't use vegetable oil or that much fat in my baking. I substituted an additional cup of pumpkin and a half cup of butter for the one and a half cups of vegetable oil. Also, unfortunately my friend did not have any cloves, so I omitted that. The bread was exceptionally moist and delicious. I know it would have been delicious with the cloves as well. I will definitely make this again, next time with the cloves and maybe increasing the spices as one reviewer suggested.

text:
YUM, loved it!!! Here are my healthy alterations: used only 1 cup of white flour and substituted 1 cup finely ground raw sunflower seeds and 1 cup finely ground oats for the rest of the flour. I used 1 cup of sugar instead of 2, added 1/2 cup of honey. I also added 3 tsp of vanilla, one egg, used only 1/2 cup of oil and increased the baking powder by a smidge, and added 1/4 tsp of cardamon. I made them in muffin tins. The muffins ROSE (I was surprised thinking they would be flatter because of the gluten free ingredient additions!). EXCELLENT texture and will definitely make these again and again!!!!!!!!!

text:
While this was a good basic recipe, I think I would change a few things the next time I make this. It had an overwhelming flavor of vegetable oil.  I would have preferred butter.  Plus, the ratio of spices to the amount of batter was too little.  I would probably increase it to 2 Tbsp. Cinnamon, 1 Tbsp. Ground Ginger (not a fan of cloves) and 1 Tbsp. of Grated Nutmeg.  I also don't own 3 loaf pans, so I made a dozen muffins (baked for 20 mins.) and served them with a cream cheese frosting.  My frosting was the only way I could mask the flavor of the vegetable oil.

This is an awesome recipe.  I made it almost just as written, but I used a full 28 ounce can of pumpkin, slightly less sugar (1/2 cup less or so) and I used 4.5 tsp. of pumpkin pie spice in place of the individual cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves.  I made this into 3 dozen muffins: plain for the first two batches, then added chocolate chips for the last batch.  I sprinkled cinnamon sugar on top and baked each batch for 22-24 minutes as other reviewers suggested.  Deeeeeeelicious!

text:
This was a fantastic recipe.  I don't normally change up a recipe until after I have made it exactly as written but I did not have all the spices on hand so I substituted with pumpkin pie spice and used a whole 30oz can of pumpkin.  Other than that I made no other changes and managed to get one loaf and almost 2 and a half dozen muffins from this recipe.  It's very simple to make and holds very well for at least 4 days (that's how long they lasted with only 3 people in my household).  I will definitely make this again, may even add a bit more pumpkin.  Thank you Cheryl for the tastey recipe.

I have made this recipe 3 times in the last week and a half. I received a good sized pumpkin in my Farm Share and it yielded a lot of pumpkin! Every time I made this it turned out great. My mixer isn't large enough to accommodate the recipe as is, so I shrunk one batch to 1/3 of the recipe and the other two batches to 2/3 of the recipe. Each one turned out great.  The only change I made was adding 1 tsp of vanilla extract. YUM! I made a couple loaves, and lots of muffins and mini muffins. They will be great to freeze and add to my kids lunches as a sweet surprise. Thank you for this recipe!

text:
LOVE this recipe, bursting with spice flavor! Co worker said it was absolutely the best pumpkin bread she ever tried so I gave her the recipe with my minor changes.  Used 2 full 14 oz cans pumpkin puree. Completely substituted oil with 1 1/2 cups of cinnamon apple sauce since that is the kind I had. Added 1 1/2 tspns of allspice and 1 tspn vanilla. Added chips for kids, but I love it on its own. I may try Ginger next time just for fun (I love ginger). I made 2 loaves and about 18 muffins from the mix in same oven. Muffins took about 20 minutes. I will make this for my niece's baby shower.

text:
This is a fantastic recipe, I have made it several times already, and I am doing so again now.  I have juiced it up just a bit, I make my own pumpkin mash, add 2 teaspoons Nutmeg and 2 Teaspoons Ground CLove 2 teaspoons cinnamon.  Also I like to add 2 apples that I have covered in sugar and cinnamon cut into small pieces,  After the batter is mixed I add the apple chunks and just kinda fold them in.  Comes deliciously moist, the extra spices give a really great fall smell and taste.  Your mouth will be watering as it cooks and once they come out 3 loaves does not last long!

text:
I changed this recipe as I was making it because when I halved the recipe the proportions seemed way off.  It was very dry, almost a dough rather than a batter....SO, I added twice as much pumpkin puree and I'm glad I did.  They turned out great (I did jumbo muffins, 30 minutes at 350)...One more tip is that I beat the eggs with a whisk for a minute before adding for a bit of airiness... and I also added ground ginger and less sugar.

text:
I have made this two times now.  The first time I substituted a half a cup of oil w/ apple sauce.  It was soo delicious! Two loafs went to work with my hubs and they loooved it! 
The second time I substituted a majority of the oil with apple sauce.  Not a fan!!!!  I know its healthier but it was just not good.  My husband did not even want want to take it to work for the guys.  Actually most of it got thrown out.  I would not suggest making it this way.  I know its healthier but it is also not good.  
Both times I sprinkled the bread with sanding sugar and that gives it a pretty look and an extra yum!

text:
Delicious! I halved the recipe and made 18 regular-sized muffins. Baked for 29 minutes in my oven. For the halved recipe, I used one whole 15oz can of pumpkin. I also used 1C white sugar and 1C packed brown sugar, instead of 2C white sugar. Because I hate having to scrub muffin tins, I did use cupcake wrappers and the muffins did not stick at all for me (as another reviewer had mentioned they did). Cooled for about 10 minutes in the tins and then removed them to the cooling rack. They've only been out of the oven for 1/2 hour and I've already eaten two!

text:
This came out great.  I made it lower in fat by using 1 c unsweetened applesauce and 1/2 c oil. I made 2 loaves (filling the pans 3/4 full) and 12 muffins out of this much batter. I  made a streusel topping out of brown sugar, butter, flour and cinnamon for one of the loaves and the mufffins.  My only mistake was using cupcake papers in the muffin tins.. they stuck to the paper pretty bad so next time I will try to remember to just grease the muffin tins. Thanks for the awesome recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Used others' suggestions of cutting back slightly on oil and increasing spices to 2 tsp each. These changes worked great. Next time I might even add a little more of the spices. Bread is great but maybe a bit plain (sort of like a pumpkin pancake in loaf form). I think raisins would be the perfect antidote, adding another level of texture and flavor. Made a pan of 12 muffins (baked for 25min), one 8x4 loaf (baked for 50min), and one 9x5 loaf (baked for 1hour25min). Baked all three at once in the oven.  The only issue with baking was the very top of everything would be slightly undercooked despite the rest being perfectly done. Haven't figured out a solution to this, but perhaps I'll just have to bake longer and hope it doesn't dry out.

country:
None
text:
I bake a lot, and my roommate just told me "I think this is the best thing you've made so far". I made a few modifications: 
-reduced recipe to 2/3 original volume
-omitted cloves (didn't have any)
-added 1 tsp ground ginger
-(from reduced recipe) replaced 2 tablespoons of flour with 2 tablespoons cocoa powder
-added ~1 cup chocolate chips
-baked as muffins, 20 mins at 350

amazing. I'm saving this recipe and I will make it again!

text:
This was really good. We made this for Thanksgiving & it was super easy to make. We made the first batch exactly to recipe & it turned out really good, but too sweet. It's really a cake, not bread. The second batch we used only 3 cups sugar & substituted unsweetened applesauce in place of the oil. (Also cut down the cloves to 1/2 teaspoon, but just for personal taste.) It turned out a lot less sweet, but had the same moist, fluffy texture. I'll be making it again for Christmas as a bundt cake with a cream icing cheese drizzle. ^_^

Display Name:
ChefsGoneWild

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this recipe 5 stars for its reliable texture and moistness.  I have just a few suggestions:  If you factor the servings to 24 you get a very simple recipe to follow and two 5X8" loaves to be proud of.  If you make the 36 serving recipe it will produce 2-5X8" loaves and 24 cupcake sized muffins.  Save yourself the stress and use paper cups...  Do not put more than 2lbs. of batter in a loaf.  The top will be too dark by the time the bread is cooked (200F).  Don't be afraid to play with it.  I added 1C. each of raisans and craisans maserated in 1/4C. Marsala wine.  You can reduce the sugar for your own taste, but I found that it needs the oil.  One last pointer, use freshly ground spices.  It makes all the difference!  Bon Appetito--Chef Chris

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was super good! I brought it to my book group and everyone liked it. I did change a couple things, however, because of my preferences. First, I had read in another review that you can substitute all of the oil for unsweetened applesauce to make it healthier, and wanted to give it a try. We didn't have any applesauce, so my mom had the idea that I mash up some canned (unsweetend) pears and use that instead. It worked beautifully! I did use a 3 to 1 ratio of pear puree to oil, just to be safe, but in the future, I'll use all pear. Also, I decreased the amounts of nutmeg and cloves and increased the amount of cinnamon, just because that's how my family likes it. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Very easy recipe. I took the suggestion of others and used pumpkin pie spice but didn't omit the ground cloves in the original recipe. I think this was a mistake on my part and next time will omit the cloves and just use the pumpkin pie spice and maybe a little more cinnamon. I actually reduced the recipe amount to make 24 servings and used 2c of sugar instead of the amount called for. I felt 2 cups was plenty and could use even less. The 24 serving size yielded 72 mini muffins and I only had to bake the mini muffins for 15 minutes. Great recipe - thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My sister and I love the Pumpkin Muffins from Panera Bread and I have long searched for a recipe that would be equivalent. This is nearly it. I think the cloves were a little stronger than what Panera uses but it was still awesome! Panera uses a cinnamon walnut streusel topping on the top though so I will be doing that next time(I used to work there-lol)  For anyone wanting to make this in a bread machine: I was able to do this easily. The recipe was rather large so I cut it down to a 1/3. I added all the ingredients into the bread pan in the order listed in the recipe. Then I set my bread machine to the 'express' setting. It may be called 'cake' or 'quick breads' on some machines. Some machines may not have it but mine did so it works well. Cutting the recipe down to 1/3 made for a small loaf- probably about 1.5 pounds but my machine can make up to a 3 pound loaf so will probably just half the original recipe next time.  My hubby loved it and says that I have to make this all the time now. The real test will be when my sister comes over tomorrow for some. ^_^

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/182797.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe many times. Everyone loves it, especially kids. The recipe is delicious exactly as it appears here.  It is also delicious modified to make it healthier. I've replaced some of all of the flour with wheat flour; some all of the vegetable oil with apple sauce (the more you use the more the flavor becomes pumpkin-apple); and and I've replaced some or all of the sugar with agave and/or honey. The recipe is always good. My only complaint is that the top gets sticky the second day, whether you store it on the counter or in the refrigerator. The only way I've come up with that helps is to replace some of the sugar with brown sugar, which is also delicious. (Or, just toast it and spread cream cheese on it.) Oh, and, don't hesitate to thrown in some extra pumpkin, and just plan to cook it a little longer. And, it freezes well (but the top is a little sticky). Delicious! A family favorite.

This is the best pumpkin bread ever! I used to be addicted to Starbuck's pumpkin loaf, but this is much less expensive. I usually cut the recipe in half and it makes 18-20 muffins, so it only takes about 15-18 minutes to cook, or they'll get dry. My very picky two year old will eat 3 of these in a row. They're great for lunch boxes and sharing with neighbors. I just tried adding chocholate chips to some of the muffins and about died when I had one~ YUM!!!

text:
This recipe was really easy and yummy!  I substituted all of the oil with natural applesauce. The applesauce does change the texture a little, but if you are looking to cut calories, it is not too noticeable and worth it!  I didn't double my spices but put heaping amounts in and it was very tasty.  (My spices are brand new, so very strong.) I made 6 mini loaves (all connected in one pan) which took about 20 minutes to bake.

This was amazing.  I scaled it to make 2 loaves, added more pumpkin than called for because I needed to use it up, and used part whole wheat, white whole wheat, and regular flour.  If you use whole wheat a secret is to add a splash of orange juice, they just go together, even though it sounds odd.  Even the picky kids liked it.

Update: just made it again used a whole 290z can of pumpkin, and doubled the spice or more than doubled.  It was great, the husband and kids loved it.  I added a cup on whole wheat and you didn't notice it.  I made 2 loaves and 12 muffins.  The muffins were obviously done and a little more than half the time of the loaves.

Okay, I am in love with this bread.  It took me 5 minutes to whip it together.  My oven baked it perfectly in the exact time the recipe posted.  I did add an extra 1/4 cup of flour because I live in a high altitude.  It made a beautiful Bundt cake and one large loaf.  I did post a picture of this recipe. As with most quick breads, it tasted better the next day. You will have to hide it from the family though or it will never last that long

text:
This recipe was wonderful!!! Here are the modifications I made: I added 1 small shredded zucchini (I couldn't decide if I wanted to make zucchini or pumpkin bread, so I made both), used fresh pumpkin, used whole wheat flour instead of white, used only 2 cups of white sugar and about 1 cup of pure maple syrup (it was still plenty sweet), and used only about 1/2 cup of oil and 1 cup of apple sauce. The bread came out super moist and everyone gobbled it up - even the picky kids. Enjoy!

text:
This recipe is outstanding.  I added chocolate chips and cream cheese icing to the top. Even my 3 year old loves it. The only problem I had was that my bread took an hour and 35 minutes to bake and it still looked gooey at towards the bottom middle.  The top was deep brown, but certainly not over cooked.  I did make sure that the top sprung back when lightly pushed on.  I baked the 3 loaves together, two in metal pans one in a glass pan.  The one in the glass pan had to be left in ~5 minutes longer than the others.  I plan on baking this for others as a gift, or just to share. Great!

text:
My wife is pregnant and had some pumpkin bread at a patch nearby and loved it so I thought I would make her some.  This turned out perfect!  I made this at halftime during a Sunday game with almost no effort.  Three loafs, 45-50 minutes and a perfect texture.  

I used 1/2 cup less sugar and added 1 tsp on ginger as well.  Next time I will modify just slightly and use 2tsp of nutmeg and cinnamon, 1 tsp of cloves and 1 tsp of ginger.  I didn't add ginger as some say, but that couldn't hurt.  Also, there is a post saying how a 28oz tin of puree gives an extra 1/2 cup, well I measured a 29oz tin (don't know why they'd have this size) and it just barely filled the three cups.

Delicious! I made a few changes though as recommended by other reviewers. I didn't change the oil amount (because I didn't have any applesauce and I also figured a cup and a half divided over 3 loaves wasn't too too bad). I used two 14 oz cans of pumpkin, 1 and half cups each white and brown sugar, cut the cloves to 1 tsp, upped the cinnamon and nutmeg to 2 tsps each and added 1/2 a tsp of pumpkin spice and topped it all with cream cheese icing!  It is fabulous and was awesome this morning with my coffee. My husband and two year old love it too!

text:
This is a fabulous and delicious recipe! I followed the suggestion given by many of using half oil and half applesauce. And used two tsp of cinnimon and nutmeg and 1 1/2 tsp of cloves. I thought vanilla would be a great enhancement and it was perfect using 2 tsp. I made two loaves one without chopped pecans and one with pecans just to have some variety at Thanksgiving. And with the rest of the batter I added cranberries and made muffins for snacks and breakfast. I recieved many complements about how flavorful and moist the bread is and I'll be sure to make this tasty treat a tradition at Thanksgiving. Also having whipped pumpkin cream cheese on the side was a great addition for people to spread on the pumpkin bread that didn't have any pecans or cranberries in it. Go to your local bagel shop like Einstein Bros Bagels or Noah's and they usually carry this around in October and November.
