city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe- especially with alterations. I added some walnuts, used 3 whole eggs, 2 egg whites, instead of six. I also used half a cup of splenda baking blend in place of one cup of sugar and half a cup of splenda's brown sugar blend and a cup of regular  brown sugar in place of the other two cups. I used cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger and pumpkin spice liberally (well over 1 and a half tsps of each). I used a cup and a half each of white flour and wheat flour, and 1 and 3/4ths cup of oats. I made both muffins (about 24) and a full sized loaf out of this batch, which I topped with a little brown sugar and some oats. Excellent- very moist, flavorful. Wonderful base recipe, but use your imagination and some cooking sense and you'll end up with something fabulous.

This is a great recipe.  Tastes like Thanksgiving. :)  Next time I make it, I'll try adding less cloves, though.  1 1/2 teaspoons was a bit overpowering.  Actually left a funny after taste.  Maybe half the cloves and more cinnamon.  One might even try a dash of ginger for even more kick.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cut the recipe in half, which made one large loaf and one small. I didn't bother to measure the pumpkin, just figured one can was abut what was called for...it worked out perfectly. I'm not sure how long I baked my loaves, but obviously the smaller one less time. I think I started checking it after about 45 minutes, and just let it go until a toothpick came out fairly clean. 

The only other modification I made was to sprinkle raw sugar on top of the loaves before baking. My family just likes the crunchy, sweet topping that makes, so I do that on most quick-breads.

The end result---we loved these delicious, most pumpkin loaves!  We will definitely make this recipe again.

text:
Great recipe for a rich, dense bread. Like others, I used a full can of pumpkin (29 oz.) and substituted half of the oil with cinnamon applesauce. I also doubled the spices, except the ground cloves (a little overpowering) where I used 1tsp. ground cloves and 2 tsp. allspice. I cut the sugar back to half and substituted brown sugar for white. These are great as they are, but sometimes I fancy them up with cream cheese frosting!

I've used this recipe for 2 years in a row. I love it. Instead of all oil, however, I use 1 cup of melted butter and 1/2 cup of the oil. I, also, brush it with butter out of the oven and cover it in a glaze drizzle. It's a bread that freezes well, so you can eat it throughout the year.

text:
Woot! Having made this recipe now 5 times and gone through 3 huge pumpkins for the fresh pulp I can say this recipe rocks. The measurements are easy to remember. The combination of cinnamon, cloves and nutmeg gives the bread a rich taste and delightful olfactory bang. It’s a relatively quick prep if you just want to use pulp from the can (one occasion). The best part though is that you end up with 3 loaves and the creative juices begin to flow. So far this year I’ve treated a few neighbors to surprise loaves and snuck a loaf into the freezer for a certain Turkey themed holiday. In return folks have offered me Canadian Ale and glad smiles... what standard recipe does all that

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I first bought the canned pumpkin in hopes of enticing my finicky senior dog to eat; read it was great for them and they loved it! Well, he wasn't interested, so ... now what? Looked for a great pumpkin recipe and this one jumped out at me. Changes I made: Like some of the others, I just used the whole can of puree (minus a teaspoon, lol) which at 29 ounces is  just over 3 1/2 cups; used 1 1/2 cups (sweet) applesauce instead of veg oil; halved the sugar; and doubled the spices. Made two loaves (an hour in the 350 oven was just about right) and 12 muffins (40 min.) The result? Moist, slightly chewy,  flavorful pieces of autumn that my husband can't stop eating. Really delicious! I'm going to try some of the other cooks' takes -- chocolate chips, nuts, raisins.  This is a recipe I'll be using for a very long time. (Gave a tiny piece to my dog -- who of course loved it. Go figure.) ;)

text:
I made this vegan and without sugar. I substituted all the eggs for bananas of various size (so 6 bananas), and I added a bit of stevia (probably about 1 tbs). I also added maybe 1 tsp of ground ginger. It came out great! The tops are a little hard, as this will happen when replacing eggs with bananas in baking, but it is so moist, and I'm pleased with the amount of sweetness. :) If you want to go the route I did, I would probably suggest adding more stevia to taste! Also as other reviewers suggested, I would cut the cloves by half. I'll make this again for sure.

text:
Excellent pumpkin bread. I did make some of the modifications suggested - 50/50 mix of brown and white sugar and substituted applesauce for 1/2 the oil.  For fun holiday gifts, I baked the batter in 8 pint wide-mouth canning jars as detailed in "Banana Nut Bread Baked in a Jar" recipe on this site.  The bread was terrific and the presentation in the canning jars was really fun to do.  The canning jars work nicely not only for gifts but for smaller families if you don't want to commit to eating two whole loaves at once (although it is tempting).

Display Name:
Sweet Dee

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5110870.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this into muffins and it yielded 42. Also, I baked at 18 minutes (some other reviewers noted baking muffins between 22-24, but that would have been way too long for mine). Not sure why my bake time was so much less, I'm at a super low altitude (Pensacola beach, FL) but keep an eye on them!

I also substituted unsweetened applesauce for half of the oil. I used almost all of the sugar (~3.5 cups) called for because I didn't want to move to far away from the original recipe, but I wonder if I could have used cinnamon applesauce (sweetened) and cut more of both oil and sugar. I'll have to try that next time.

Funny story, I was making these late at night and in my tired state, used almost 2 TABLESPOONS of cinnamon (face smack). I had meant to increase from 1.5 tsp to 2 tsp, not TBS. I shrugged it off and still added the additional spices (but at the suggested amount) and they still turned out great! Not too cinnamon-y, which of course is what I was worried about. I do love cinnamon though but my husband didn't notice so I think it's safe to say, you can definitely go heavier on the cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves. 

Yum, typing up this review is making me hungry - time to go eat one of my muffins! You can't go wrong with this one :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVED it!!!  Best recipe I’ve ever used. Better then my all time favorite Starbucks pumpkin bread. As suggested in another review; I reduced the sugar; 1.5 cup white sugar and 1 c brown. It was Plenty sweet.  1 cup oil, 1/2 apple sauce.  It’s perfectly moist.   I chop pumpkin seeds and sprinkle on top. I use Nonstick tin liners,  and after 45 min I start to check center of the loaf with a toothpick, and every 2-5 min after, until toothpick comes out clean.  It’s very disappointing to over-bake and dry out the bread. I cool the bread, slice it, wrap it in Reynolds freezer paper, stick it in a freezer Gal bag, and freeze it. Every morning I take out a slice and place it in a ziplock bag. It’s perfect by mid morning school snack time. My kids Love it!!!

city:

country:

text:
Loved this recipe.  I made muffins (about 23 min bake time).  I made some big changes because I needed to use up some butternut squash I had cooked the night before and didn't eat.  I peeled it, pureed it and then used it exactly like pumpkin.  I did add more spices to this bc I didn't want to taste squash and had to add a little milk to it as well because butternut squash seemed to be much stickier.   So just FYI: I lowered the sugar by a cup, lowered the oil by 1/4 cup as well, I also replaced 1.75 cups of all purpose flour with whole wheat flour because I just wanted to make it a little healthier and no one even would taste the difference at all!!   I know, I know, I know... I changed the recipe... how can I rate it??  Well, I'm not rating it poorly.  But I needed to use my squash up and this little switcharoo turned out GREAT.  (and I have LOTS more butternut squash puree left... 3 cups was about 1/2 a good size squash)  My boyfriend heard I made butternut squash bread and he almost didn't want to try it when he stopped by this evening, but he did and was very surprised it tasted just like pumpkin muffins.  It was wonderful.  Thank you!!!

userID:

Display Name:
bmcdonald01

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this a few days ago.  Cut the recipe in half just in case it didn't turn out.  One 15-oz can of pumpkin yields 1-3/4 c. pumpkin, just a little more than  what would be needed for 1/2 the recipe so I used the whole can.  I also did not have ground cloves so subbed pumpkin pie spice.  It made two loaves.  Took about an hour bake time.  

When the loaves cooled, I drizzled some icing left over from a package of cinnamon rolls.  Bread was very nice and moist.  

Rating it four stars instead of five because of the high amount of sugar; also, flavor didn't "knock my socks off"--pumpkin itself is rather mild so the spices are what boosts the flavor.  The icing added a bit to the taste.  Keeping the recipe and may come back to it.  Have plenty of other pumpkin bread recipes I plan to try.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
I've made this recipe so many times now. Over the last three years I've made mini loves as Christmas gifts and everyone calls it pumpkin pie bread. I don't change a hung in the recipe- maybe cook a little longer for regular size loaves. It is great as muffins! This bread also freezes great! I freeze whole loaves, slices and muffins and they are great. One final note, I see several people say they skip the different spices and use pumpkin pie spice- I'm sure it's delicious that way but to me the hefty amount of ground cloves make this bread.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it again and much better with the following changes: 3/4 c unsalted butter and 1c unsweetened applesauce (3 containers of apple sauce snacks) for the oil; 1/2c brown sugar & 2 1/2c coconut sugar ( or just use brown sugar if you don't have coconut sugar) ; 1 3/4c whole wheat flour; 3 c all purpose flour; 1 1/2 tbsp cinnamon; 2 tsp nutmeg; 1 1/2c raw shelled pumpkin seeds; 2c dried cranberries ( craisins). I also used parchment paper to line the loaf pans so no need to grease the pans! Top with some craisins prior to baking and lowered temperature to 325 degrees to bake at 55 mins and turned out super moist and full of flavour!

text:
This is a great simple recipe! The only changes I made were: I cut the recipe in thirds because it was just a test run, so I only made one loaf. I also only added about 3/4 cup of sugar (instead of the 1 1/3 cups that it called for) because the original recipe called for a lot. Lastly, I used 1 1/2 tsp. of Apple Pie Seasoning from Penzeys instead of 1/2 tsp of cloves, nutmeg, and cinnamon. It turned out a little bit dry, and it wasn't like "WOW!" which are the only reasons I didn't give it 5 stars, but it's definitely good for a simple recipe. :) Might add chocolate chips next time.

text:
Delicious light muffins and bundt cake! Thanks for a great recipe. I used fresh pumpkin puree (our own). I did substitute 2 cups whole wheat flour for AP, and 1 1/4 cups yogurt for the same quantity of oil. I added a tsp of baking soda and one of powdered ginger. I used 4 eggs instead of 6. It had a beautiful brown slightly crisp crust, with a soft, well-baked and spice-flavored interior. I had tried other recipes before without much success, so I am really pleased with the way this one turned out.

country:
None
text:
I have made this so many times .   I love that it makes three loaves it doesn't take any extra time and I put two in the freezer for later. 
 Like everything else I make I alter the recipe.  I don't use any vegetable oil I, use equal parts butter, coconut oil, and avocado oil.  I substitute some coconut flour for a portion of the flour, and some coconut sugar and Stevia for a portion of the sugar 
 I also grind nuts to a texture of almost a meal and then add that in with the flour.  I also add in some small dark chocolate chips and I add in about a quarter cup of molasses to the batter 
 Finally I use cooked pumpkin that I do in the fall. Sometimes my portions are short of 3 cups. If they are I make up the difference with mashed bananas

text:
I make snacks for 100+ children at a daycare, so I tried this, leaving out the nutmeg and cloves to make it more toddler-friendly. I made just one other change, because our daycare avoids the use of oil in baking: I substituted melted butter for the oil, and I can't detect a flavor difference.  Instead of greasing and flouring the pans, I just spray with oil spray, which works perfectly and is less trouble. I baked six loaves and it was a big hit with both the kids and the teachers. The kids asked for "more cake" in requesting seconds! It's really easy to make in quantity, too! This has now become one of the daycare's standard snacks in rotation. Thanks, Cheryl, for a great recipe!

This was wonderful. I've never had pumpkin bread before and so it didn't taste as strongly of pumpkin as I expected it to but that might be on the fault of the pumpkin I used. I made the puree myself from an extra Halloween pumpkin. Next time, I'll use either a pumpkin pie pumpkin, or just buy a couple of cans of pumpkin. 

With that said, I loved it. I halved the sugar due to personal preference and it was perfect. Really moist, tender crumb. Smells fantastic, and it's really filling.
I made one loaf with nothing added, one loaf with raisins and walnuts, and one loaf with chocolate chips and they were all wonderful. 

Definitely making this again.

text:
This recipe has been my favorite so far for pumpkin loafs. I adjusted the recipe a little bit to fit my ingredients on hand and it turned out perfectly (I didn't include the ground cloves and used only 2 cans of pumpkin puree). I'll definitely make it the same way next time. 

It also made a lot more than I realized, two loafs and one dozen muffins. I was too tired to bake it all the day I put it together so I actually refrigerated half of it and it kept well for 3 days. When I baked the last portion, I actually think it tasted better after the ingredients set in the fridge! This will definitely be my 'go to' recipe from now on.

text:
I've made this lots of times - it's delicious every time!  I have made some changes over time: cut the oil down to no more than 1 1/4 C, cut the sugar down to 3 C, use the entire can of pumpkin,  1T each cin & nutmeg, 2tsp clove, add about 1 1/2 bags of chocolate chunks.  Oh, and I use a hodge podge of pans- smaller "gift" tins and medium loaf (and usually one regular loaf).  This means I have to do two rounds of baking but 45mins is usually fine for the smaller ones.  My son LOVES this! :)

text:
The best recipe.  I didn't plan ahead the first time I made this and only had 1 cup reg. sugar.  So I used that, the remaining 1 1/2c raw sugar I had on hand (ground fine in a coffee grinder), and 1/2 c honey.  Turned out wonderful.  Not sweet but very flavorful.  The second time, I followed the directions as-is (actually, the video) and it turned out wonderful.  Sweeter than my first attempt and a more subtle flavor, but still great.  So now I have 2 variations from 1 recipe!!

text:
I made this last night and it was outstanding. This was the most moist and delicious pumpkin bread I have ever had...and I can't believe I made it. I gave some to a neighbor who didn't try it in front of me, but he sent my husband a text telling him that he loves me because although he didn't know what pumpkin bread was before yesterday, he said it was amazing. I didn't add as much sugar as the recipe called for so it could have been a tad sweeter (to my husband and son) but I think it's perfect. I will definitely make this again, for my house and to give away.
One thing I would like to note is I made this for 24 servings and added a teaspoon and a half of vanilla extract, two teaspoons of cinnamon, instead of one and a teaspoon and a half of nutmeg instead of one. Without those additions, I don't think it would have been as good.

text:
OK, this isn't bread, its un-frosted cake! SOOOO yummy! The first time I made it, I ran out of oil so I substituted butter. It was extremely decadent. This time, I tried using only 3 cups of sugar, and its still awesome. I asked my 5 y/o if it was as good as the first one, and he said, "even gooder" so you wont miss that extra cup. You could probably use even less, but don't skip the chocolate chips. Oh, and this time I used 1/2 bag chocolate chips, and 1/2 bag pecans.

WOW!  Very esay to make, and everyone that has tasted it has commented positively on the taste, and the moistness of it.  I normally make a mixture of loaves and muffins together. Cut up, and cook one apple in mocrowave with water 30 seconds, puree it, then add oil to make the 1 1/2 cups that the recipe calls for.  Delish!

text:
This recipe was only so-so for me. I tried it twice, once with Fresh pumpkin, and once with fresh AND canned pumpkin.  It did NOT taste like pumpkin, I must say.  The first time I overdid the spices (my fault) and ended up with to much cloves. Second time though, I doubled the recipe and added both fresh and canned pumpkin.  Still had not a whole lot of pumpkin flavor. It tasted somewhat like Banana Bread, minus the Banana flavor. I will probably go back to using my mother's recipe for pumpkin bread, which was WAAAY better, and requires yeast. Only reason I didn't use that is it calls for yeast and I just didn't have the time this year to commit to a yeast recipe. I will MAKE the time from here on out!

text:
Definite keeper!  I subbed 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce and cut back on the sugar by about 1/2 cup.  It made one large loaf, 6 mini loaves and 24 mini muffins.  SO easy, super moist and definitely delicious!  Can't wait to bring them to work tomorrow and also give out to neighbors!  Oh, and I would probably cut back on more of the oil and the sugar without missing it...once I sprinkle a little bit of confectioner's sugar on them, they'll be perfect!  Thanks for a fabulous recipe!

Tasty and easy! I made one 9x5 loaf and two 8x3's. The bread not only smells wonderful, but is super moist and not too sweet. text:
This bread is amazing! It is very moist, and the spices taste fantastic in it! I cut the recipe to make 2 loaves I did have to bake it a little longer than the time on the recipe..I'm not sure if it was because of my oven or not. I ended up cooking the two loaves for 1 hour and 15 minutes instead of the 45 mins-1 hour. This recipe is so simple and takes no time at all to make! Of the two loves, I brought one to a family get-together this weekend, everyone raved about how great it was! The other loaf I kept at home for my husband and roommates - I made the bread on Saturday morning, and the whole loaf, except for two pieces, had disappeared by Sunday evening! This would be a great item to bring to Thanksgiving dinner! I will definitely be making this pumpkin bread again this fall!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe.  I did make a few changes, but I am sure it is wonderful as is:  I used unsweetened apple sauce in place of the oil, and I also added an equal amount of Pumpkin Pie Spice in addition to the cinnamon, cloves, and nutmeg.  I halved the recipe, and still used about 2 cups of pumpkin puree, and about 1/4 cup more flower to help balance out the extra puree.  I got two 4.5 x 8.5 loaves out of it, one plain and one I added raisins.  I baked them in glass loaf pans for a good hour.  They turned out wonderful!!  This is now my got-to pumpkin bread recipe.  I didn't find it too sweet, but next time I will try cutting back on the sugar as well.

text:
I've made this twice. The first time it was the hit of our Christmas dinner! My boyfriend begged me to make it again! I followed the directions except I substituted pumpkin spice for the cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves. The second time I made it... I have to admit, I messed up. I didn't have the pumpkin spice and I only had cinnamon and cloves. So I made it without the nutmeg and forgot the salt! It wasn't as good... everyone could tell something was missing. I also used half oil and half apple sauce to make it a bit healthier. I'm not sure if it affected the taste also, but it definitely didn't affect the moisture, because it was still nice and moist.

text:
I actually overcooked the 2 loaves I made and found something very interesting. The first loaf we ate was dry and over-cooked tasting. The second loaf I wrapped and stuck in the refrigerator for about 2 weeks. When I finally took it out to see if it was edible or if I should throw it away - it was delicious! Something about sitting made everything as moist and delicious as it should have been. Any bread that springs back from a mistake like that is a winner in my book!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made this with a few changes (I never follow a recipe 100%. I only made 1/2 of the batch (18 muffins). I had cooked pumpkin in the fridge so used almost 2 cups of that instead of canned pumpkin. I used about 1/4 cup canola oil and 1/4 olive oil and 1/4 cup cooked peaches (cooked without sugar). I put the oils with peaches into smaller blender and mixed thoughly. Instead of 2 cups of sugar I used 1 cup splenda and 1/2 white sugar. Instead of using all flour I took large oatmeal flakes and put them into the food processor and made into oat flour (bit courser the flour) and used 1 1/3 cups of that with 1 cup all-purpose flour. Used all the spices as if I was making a full recipe and also throw in about 1/2 tsp cardamon. These came out light and fuffly and as I seen in one review served with cool-whip which I happened to have thawed and in the fridge. These are really good and think I will make some more and bring to work to treat everybody.

text:
This is amazing bread! I've been in a pumpkin mood lately and have been searching for as many recipes that use pumpkin puree as possible. This one is a keeper! I love how with applesauce there is very little fat and it is super moist! Instead of the reccommended amount of flour, I used about half whole wheat flour and half whole wheat oats, then a few tablespoons of flax seed. It has a wonderful texture, and with dried cranberries and chopped walnuts, there are little flavor bursts throughout. I'll definitely be making this again - especially as gifts for the holiday season

country:
None
text:
I made this in two separate batches, one with sugar and one batch with Splenda (white and brown). I made mini-loaves. Both batches turned out fine.
However, the batch made with real sugar was moister than the sugar-free batch.
But then again, the sugar-free batch was better as a quick "bread" in comparison to the sweeter sugar version, which was more like a dessert cake.
I also added different add-ins to each little loaf. I tried dried cranberries, whole flax seed, hazelnuts, chocolate chips, and all the loaves came out great. 
Great recipe...so versatile.

I didn't need or want three full size loaves, so I made 1/3 of the recipe. I thought it called for too much ground cloves so I cut them by half, but still, the fragrance was overpowering (but fortunately didn't taste that way). I also added some ground ginger. The flavor and texture of this bread was wonderful - smooth and very moist. I'm giving it four stars only because of the amount of cloves called for, and having to scale the recipe down. But I'll definitely make it again.

Very good.  I thought it was going to be too much for my kitchen aid mixer, as when I started adding the flour, it got bigger and bigger in my mixer, but I was able to contain it all. 
My first two loaves (I only had two loaf pans) took much longer than 1 hour to cook through, but the second pan took only about an hour.  I may have overfilled the first two pans, though.
I froze two of the loaves and have already polished off the third.  Thank you for sharing!

text:
I loved this!!  I have made it two different ways. The way the recipe is presented with mini chocolate chips added. Fantastic. The other way was my attempt at a lower calorie version. I used Splenda instead of white sugar, applesauce instead of oil and Egg Beaters instead of eggs. I baked the bread in a mini loaf pan (as I remember, I had to adjust the baking time to less time, but I don't remember by how much). I froze what we weren't going to be eating, and they were still yummy when thawed out. My lower calorie version was a touch drier than the original recipe, but not by much. Good stuff!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had some leftover dried cranberries and white choc. chips and other hangers-on from cookie bakes so decided to throw them together in this pumpkin bread.  this is equally as good as the downeast maine pumpkin bread recipe on allrecipes.  I used the rest of my white choc chips, dried cranberries, pecans, a few raisins, and a few mini choc. chips to add to this recipe.  The breads looked like a picture and so festive with the red and white specks within.  The only advice I have is to use the biggest mixing bowl you have.  My favorite bowl is a heavy stainless steel bowl that came with an old mixmaster stand mixer and it was near the top!  next time I'll use a bigger bowl.  I did double up on the spices and added allspice instead of the ground cloves(didn't have any).  It made 2 8x5 loaves, and 3 minis.  Oh yes, if u haven't tried the white choc. cranberry cookies on here...please do...they are scrumptious!

text:
I made this using 2 cups of granulated sugar and 2 cups of brown sugar as suggested by other reviewers.  It was very good, however, I still thought that something was missing but I'm not quite sure what that "something" was.  I baked them in some really super cute wooden baking baskets from Panibois (picked up from Crate & Barrel last year) and gave a few away as gifts.  I also added a streusel topping to half of the loaves.  I liked the loaves much better with the streusel than without.  That being said, I think that next time I will add a couple of tablespoons of molasses to see if that adds some depth to the flavor.

text:
I've made a variation of this recipe several times and always get great compliments. I cut back on the cloves but add pumplin pie spice and increase the cinnamon since I like other reviewers like it spicier. I make it healthier and I think moister be replacing most of the oil with applesauce. Splenda works fine for half the sugar also. I add walnuts to the whole batch and then in each loaf pan I add chocolate chips or Orange flavored Craisins (dried cranberries).

The middle of my bread didn't get quite done, and the edges were a little overdone.  My oven bakes a little warm, so if I make this again I'll try turning the temp down a bit.
